title: Attention everyone who became a Doctor, what grade did you get in Organic Chemistry? - Quora

response.answer_text: Looks like everyone here did pretty well so I'm going to chime in to give some hope to people who still want to go to med school in spite of how they did on Ochem. I got a C+ and a B- in my 2 semesters of Ochem. By far my worst grades in undergrad. I just couldn't convert one molecule to another for the life of me. Just didn't like the subject. But you know what, being bad at Ochem didn't affect me at all in med school. Probably used Ochem less than 2% of the time in med school. The only Chem class we had by then was Biochem which involved tons of memorization of pathways. In the last 15 years of what I would consider a very successful and fulfilling medical career I probably used Ochem less than 1% of the time. So there's hope for you future docs who did terrible on Ochem, just keep on plugging and rock your other science classes. Ochem is  just a small bump on the road of a long medical journey.

I got an A for organic chemistry.   At the time it was a premedical student with a major in chemistry.  I started to sour a bit on chemistry after this course. Then I took a graduate level biochem course and got an A. After I was pretty reasonably sure that I could cut the hard sciences required for medical school I shifted my studies to humanities degree. I switched my major to Spanish and traveled abroad and had fun the rest of my undergraduate time!  To this day I am convinced that that's what allowed me to gain entrance to a top 10 medical school from a state university.

I aced both organic chemistries and both organic labs, as I could see in my mind's eye the three dimensional structure better than the structures in non-organic chemistry. Biochemistry worked the same and I did well in it also. Where I struggled was in the math involved in ordinary chemical reactions and had to work harder to get better grades. I was generally better in those subjects in which there were biological applications for chemistry. Probably, because I enjoyed biology a great deal.

As an organic chemistry professor, I can offer some insight. I have had quite a few of my students accepted to med school. Most got A's in organic, but a couple got B's. Some instructors are more difficult than others. Your MCAT score is there to level the playing field. If you get an A, and your MCAT score is low, then the reviewers will see that you don't know your stuff. The opposite is also true. You should have at least a 3.5 GPA and a solid MCAT score.

I got an A both semesters. For me it was like Boolean algebra for chemists, easy to understand and manipulate. The value of Orgo is that is it much like medical school because you need the same study skills and abilities to do well in both. As a practical matter it will not be that helpful after the first week fo Biochemistry, but it will tell the admissions boards that you have the right stuff to succeed in medical school.

As in 1 and 2.  The mechanistic reasoning came a lot more naturally to me than the mathematics in gen and analytical chem.  Also loved the lab, or rather the reagents.  Lithium aluminum hydride is a monster of a reducing agent and plenty of fun was had abusing my access to it and the many other dangerous chemicals we were given access to :-)
Got As in OChem 1 and 2. I especially enjoyed building Tinkertoy like models and MR spectroscopy. One particularly memorable lab was when we synthesized the aromatic ester in nutmeg. Good fun!

B+ semester 1, A- the next. I don’t remember my lab grades. I went onto do 2 Summers of Organic research, and worked as a lab TA for a year after. I also majored in Chemistry. These days it’s my job to help my high schooler with his science homework
My course was taught by Melvin Calvin. Highly enjoyable and I got an A+. I was a physiol/biophysics major, not premed. Didn't even think of Med school till I arranged my post-doc.
